bayo.adeniyi_: To buttress the point made by @_____.evelyn. That's the point where the audience claps. However we need to sometimes critically engage our mentors. Not just take everything that say on surface value because it justifies what we want to hear. The speaker herself whom I adore is not shabbily dressed for the occasion. So we don't just misinterpret her intentions or give her words some kind of totalitarian authority which of course she has earned as a woman and a scholar. These days everything is debatable What is decent? By whose standards, in what culture or context? We should be reflexive and conscious of these complexities so we don't end up suffering from what Onoge calls " crisis of consciousness". We [listeners/readers] as well as [scholars/speakers] should also understand and identify our own biases as seen in Brettel's book title "when they read what we write".
